Noxa autem est corpus quod nocuit, id est servus: noxia ipsum maleficium, veluti lurtum damnum rapina iniuria. 2Summa autem ratione permissum est noxae deditione de- fungi: namque erat iniquum nequitiam eorum ultra ipsorum acorpora dominis damnosam esse. Dominus noxali iudicio servi sui nomine conventus servum actori noxae dedendo liberatur. nec minus perpetuum eius dominium a domino transfertur: si autem damnum ei cui deditus est resarcierit quaesita pecunia, auxilio praetoris invito domino manumit- ttetur. Sunt autem constitutae noxales actiones aut legibus

called noxalis because the defendant had the option, if the guilt of the slave was proved, of surrendering him to the plaintiff in lieu of paying the damages assessed: ‘praetor ait... si servus insciente domino fecisse dicetur, in iudicio adiciam “aut noxam dedere ’'' Dig. 9. 3. 1. pr. Noxal actions are thus not a class of remedies apart by themselves, but only ordinary actions on delict or quasi-delict (Dig. loc. cit), in which the defendunt, being sued on a wrong not of his own commission, is allowed by special provision (ς 4 inl.) a privilege which, had the utiense been his own, he would not have enjoyed. ln principle, though not in form, they are arbitrariae (Tit. 6. 31 supr.) ; the noxae deditio is not made in accord· auce with the judge's arbitrium, but the defendant is condemned in the alternative, Tit 17. 1 inf. lf the slave died before litis contestatio in the action, the master’s liability ended, even though his death was unknown, Dig. 9. 4 39. 43 ib. 4²· 1 : by his death during the action the master's liability in damages became absolute, ib. 3. ,

It has been conjectured that noxal actions were originally the expres- sion of an absolute claim to have the offender delivered up for the exercise of private vengeance, whether his onence were delictual or merely breach of contract. The surrender of Postumius to the Samnites by the Romans with all the forms of noxae deditio (Livy ix ιο) was made as atonement for non-observance of the treaty which he had concluded with thern, and from which the Romans wished to release themselves-ut populus re- ligione solvatur. Under Roman municipal law non-fulhlment of a promise made by sponsio entailed, in the end, quasi-slavery (manus iniecti0); and the idea was consistently applied by them in international relations; cf. lhering, Geist des r. Rechts i. p. 131 ; Mr. Ο. W. Holmes’ Common Law pp. 8-12, and Mr. Poste’s note on Gaius iv. 81.
